support.p: two rectangular blocks of marble with porphyry inlays joined in the style of Cosmati opus sectile on the front

handDesc.handNote: lines 9-10 were inscribed after the first 8 lines

decoNote.p: opus sectile patterning shows a red and green border along top, sides, and bottom, although noticeably thicker on right side of bottom block and along bottom; the left border also does not meet bottom border; centered is a diamond shape bordered by red, white, and green pattern; this is enclosed by a green-and-white diamond shape with four spirals which enclose red and green circular inlays; the rest is filled in with red-and-white small triangular pattern; campus on the back, square, is set off by a simple molded cornice; top block is from top left corner of striligilated sarcophagus, with ‘strigil-shaped’ fluting across, top corniced border (with one circular hole), and inscription on back; bottom block is plain with slightly indented border along sides and bottom, also on back

provenance.p: Seen at the San Gregorio Magno al Celio in Rome as reported in the itinerary of an anonymous Gaul in 1576.
Reported in the compluvium outside the San Gregorio Magno al Celio in an ancient marble sepulcher by an anonymous author, Hispanus Chisianus.
Sold by Pino Donati in Switzerland in 1960.
Acquired by the collection of Edith Hafter in Switzerland.
Given by descent to Donati Arte Classica in Switzerland.
Owned by Galerie Chenel in Paris.
Acquired by the Yale University Art Gallery in 2015.

div.ab:
Dis Manibus.
Marcus
Fulvius Lamyrus
hic conditus est. Haec
mihi domus aeternalis
erit meis imnpendiis.
Gratias amico
Marcus
Ulpius Eutychus
amicus
et
Fulviae Charitauti
coniugi.

div.p: To the divine shades. Marcus Fulvius Lamyrus is buried here. This will be an eternal home for me from my own expense. Marcus Ulpius Eutychus, a friend, (gives) thanks to his friend and to Fulvia Charitas, his wife.

Other bibliography: E. Engström, Carmina Latina Epigraphica Post Editam Collectionem Büchelerianam In Lucem Prolata (Gothenburg-Leipzig 1912) 16; I. Cholodniak, Carmina Sepulcralia Latina (St. Petersburg 1897) 361. Brief mention in E. Wölfflin, Archiv Für Lateinische Lexikographie und Grammatik (Leipzig 1893) 169.

Line 3: hec, attested archaic form of haec, used. haec in CIL, Engström, Cholodniak; line 4: mi, attested alternative, poetic form of mihi, used. mi in CIL, Engström, Cholodniak; line 5: inpendis, alternate form of impendiis, used. impendiis, in CIL, Engström, Cholodniak; line 9: Charituti, corrected to Charitati in CIL, Engström; lines 9-10: dedication to Fulvia Charitati added by a second hand, possibly at a later date, to the bottom of the epitaph; line 10 is not centered in campus, while rest of lines maintain close to center alignment. Inconsistent interpuncts - interpuncts visible between words D(is) M(anibus) (line 1), M(arcus) Fulvius (line 2), est h⌜a⌝ec (line 3), at end of line 5, et Fulviae (line 9). CIL only notes interpuncts between M(arcus) Fulvius Lamyrus (line 1), amico M(arcus) and end of line (line 6), but interpuncts between Fulvius and Lamyrus, and amico and M(arcus) are not visible in photograph.

The specification of Fulvia Charitas as a wife does not make it clear to whom Fulvia is married to. However, since M. Fulvius Lamyrus and Fulvia Charitas share the same gentilicium, it may be presumed that they might be siblings. This is also assuming that they were not slaves (thereby sharing the gentilicium of the master), despite Lamyrus being a Greek cognomen and found among other freedmen/freedwomen, due to the lack of identification as a freedman. There is a possibility that M. Fulvius Lamyrus and Fulvia Charitas were freed individuals, or that Lamyrus perhaps freed Fulvia Charitas and married her, however this relationship is not clear. Additionally, the Fulvii are attested in places in Etruria, such as Luna, Blera, and Sutrium, which contradicts a Greek cognomen. M. Ulpius Eutychus also has a Greek cognomen, and individuals of the same name are attested in other inscriptions, but with different wives or masters, thus pointing to distinct M. Ulpius Eutychus’s. M. Ulpius Eutychus’s role beyond a “friend” is unknown, as is his contribution to the epitaph (with M. Lamyrus specifying that he paid for the epitaph). Most discussion on this inscription relates to the metrical structure that lines 3-5 try to create. I. Cholodniak suggests that a senarius would be formed if the wording of the lines was changed to haec mi domus aeterna est meis impendiis instead.
Transcription from photo and previous edition of I. Cholodniak.
